question: A.1[1.0 point] (1.0) The reactor is operating at steady state full power when the Rotary Specimen Rack (RSR) floods, as a result reactor power would:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93
Correct. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93
Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93

answers.answer: d. initially increase then return back to its initial value
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93

question: A.2 [1.0 point] (1.0) During a fuel loading, if the fuel elements are loaded to the core one by one starting near the source and proceeding toward the detector, which ONE of the following statements describes the effect of this loading sequence on the 1/M plot?

answers.answer: a. The sequence has no effect on the 1/M plot.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: b. The 1/M plot will have a less angular slope, predicting criticality for a larger number of elements.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: c. The 1/M plot will have a steeper slope, initially predicting criticality for a fewer number of elements.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: d. The 1/M plot will approach infinity. Predicting criticality would be difficult.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

question: A.3 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following describes how delayed neutrons affect control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. More delayed neutrons are produced than prompt neutrons resulting in a longer time to reach a stable subcritical countrate.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a shorter reactor period from increased leakage.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize than prompt neutrons resulting in a longer reactor period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime resulting in a longer reactor period.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Period - Reactivity Relationships

question: A.4 [1.0 point] (1.0) With the reactor on a constant positive period, which ONE of the following power changes will take the SHORTEST time?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>
Correct. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>

question: A.5 [1.0 point] (1.0) Given a source strength of 10 neutrons per second (N/sec) and a multiplication factor (Keff) of 0.8, the expected stable neutron count rate would be?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: CR=S/(1-K) = 10/0.2 = 50 N/sec
Incorrect. REF: CR=S/(1-K) = 10/0.2 = 50 N/sec
Correct. REF: CR=S/(1-K) = 10/0.2 = 50 N/sec
Incorrect. REF: CR=S/(1-K) = 10/0.2 = 50 N/sec

question: A.6 [1.0 point] (1.0) The primary reason a neutron source is installed in the core is to:

answers.answer: a. allow for testing and irradiation experiments when the reactor is shutdown
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: b. supply the neutrons required to start the chain reaction for subsequent reactor startups
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: c. provide a neutron level high enough to be monitored for a controlled reactor startup
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

answers.answer: d. increase the excess reactivity of the reactor which reduces the frequency for refueling
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Multiplication & Criticality

question: A.7 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following describes the reason for the constant rate of power change several minutes after a reactor scram from full power?

answers.answer: a. The decay of the longer lived delayed neutron precursors.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: b. The reactivity added by the fuel temperature coefficient.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: c. The decay of fission products producing photoneutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Period - Reactivity Relationships

answers.answer: d. The subcritical multiplication of source neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Period - Reactivity Relationships

question: A.8 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following describes the time period in which the maximum amount of Xe-135 will be present in the core?

answers.answer: a. 4 to 6 hours after a power decrease from 10% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation

answers.answer: b. 4 to 6 hours after a power increase from 50% to 10%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation

answers.answer: c. 6 to 11 hours after a startup to 10% power
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation

answers.answer: d. 6 to 11 hours after shutdown from 8 hours of 10% power operation
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation

question: A.9 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following coefficients will respond first to turn power during a power increase from 50% power?

answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Temperature Compensation
Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Temperature Compensation
Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Temperature Compensation
Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Temperature Compensation

question: A.10 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following terms of the six factor formula is most affected by "Poisons"?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation
Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation
Correct. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation
Incorrect. REF: Theory of Operation, Poison Compensation

question: A.11 [1.0 point] (1.0) The reactor is shutdown by 0.05 ΔK/K, this would correspond to a Keff of:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: ρ = (Keff-1)/Keff; k=0.9524
Correct. REF: ρ = (Keff-1)/Keff; k=0.9524
Incorrect. REF: ρ = (Keff-1)/Keff; k=0.9524
Incorrect. REF: ρ = (Keff-1)/Keff; k=0.9524

question: A.12 [1.0 point] (1.0) The principal source of heat following a scram from full power is from:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, p 313.
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, p 313.
Correct. REF: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, p 313.

answers.answer: d. radioactive decay of structural material
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, p 313.

question: A.13 [1.0 point] (1.0) With a 30 second period, power would double in approximately:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>; Ln2=t/30; 0.693=t/30; t=20.8
Correct. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>; Ln2=t/30; 0.693=t/30; t=20.8
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>; Ln2=t/30; 0.693=t/30; t=20.8
Incorrect. REF: P = P0 e<sup>t/Τ</sup>; Ln2=t/30; 0.693=t/30; t=20.8

question: A.14 [1.0 point] (1.0) For a thermal reactor, a reflector is used to:

answers.answer: a. absorb excess high energy neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 6.6, p 221.

answers.answer: b. provide the media for slowing down neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 6.6, p 221.

answers.answer: c. absorb excess thermal and fast neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 6.6, p 221.

answers.answer: d. reduce the amount of fuel required to achieve criticality
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Lamarsh, Section 6.6, p 221.

question: A.15 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following is associated with the most amount of energy from fission?

answers.answer: a. Kinetic energy of fission products
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93
Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93
Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93
Incorrect. REF: KSU Exam 4/28/93

question: A.16 [1.0 point] (1.0) If a control rod withdrawal for a reactor startup is conducted without the source inserted, which ONE of the following is the result? Assume the rod withdrawal rate is the same as a normal startup, criticality will:

answers.answer: a. occur at a lower count rate than normal
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: CR1(1-Keff1) = CR2(1-Keff2); If initial CR low then as Keff approaches 1.0, so will the resultant CR.

answers.answer: b. occur at a higher count rate than normal
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: CR1(1-Keff1) = CR2(1-Keff2); If initial CR low then as Keff approaches 1.0, so will the resultant CR.

answers.answer: c. occur much later than normal
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: CR1(1-Keff1) = CR2(1-Keff2); If initial CR low then as Keff approaches 1.0, so will the resultant CR.
Incorrect. REF: CR1(1-Keff1) = CR2(1-Keff2); If initial CR low then as Keff approaches 1.0, so will the resultant CR.

question: A.17 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which one of the following reactivity insertions above "just critical" on delayed neutrons will make the reactor "just prompt critical"?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh pg. 286
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh pg. 286
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh pg. 286
Correct. REF: Lamarsh pg. 286

question: A.18 [1.0 point] (1.0) Which ONE of the following factors is the most significant in determining the differential worth of a control rod?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 7.2, p 270.
Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 7.2, p 270.
Correct. REF: Lamarsh, Section 7.2, p 270.

answers.answer: d. The amount of fuel in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh, Section 7.2, p 270.

question: A.19 [1.0 point] (1.0) Using the normal operating parameters associated with the TRIGA cooling systems and with a primary side temperature difference of 6 °C, the temperature difference across the SECONDARY side of the heat exchanger would be:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Q=MCpΔT; Qp=Qs; (110 gpm)Cp(6C)= 176Cp(X); X = 660/176 = 3.8 degrees-C.
Correct. REF: Q=MCpΔT; Qp=Qs; (110 gpm)Cp(6C)= 176Cp(X); X = 660/176 = 3.8 degrees-C.
Incorrect. REF: Q=MCpΔT; Qp=Qs; (110 gpm)Cp(6C)= 176Cp(X); X = 660/176 = 3.8 degrees-C.
Incorrect. REF: Q=MCpΔT; Qp=Qs; (110 gpm)Cp(6C)= 176Cp(X); X = 660/176 = 3.8 degrees-C.

question: A.20 [1.0 point] (1.0) [DELETED] The TRIGA reactor is not allowed to be pulsed from power levels above 1kw. The reason for this requirement is:

answers.answer: a. The additional fast neutron flux from the pulse could dangerously embrittle fuel cladding.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: KSU SAR Section 7

answers.answer: b. The additional heat from the pulse could cause pool temperature limits to exceed operating specifications.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: KSU SAR Section 7

answers.answer: c. The additional thermal neutron flux from the pulse could dangerously embrittle fuel cladding.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: KSU SAR Section 7

answers.answer: d. The additional heat from the pulse could cause fuel temperature limits to be exceeded.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: KSU SAR Section 7
